summary: Victor L. Trinkala is a person of interest due to his connection with Richard C. Nagell and his underage enlistment in the U.S. Army. In 1969, an anonymous tip suggested Trinkala, en route to Vietnam and identified as a Conscientious Objector, had been contacted by a "Soviet Agent" for potential anti-U.S. propaganda. Trinkala sought discharge from the Army, claiming he was underage at enlistment, and his records incorrectly stated his birthdate. He was interviewed in February 1970 regarding his character and loyalty, during which he was perceived as reluctant. Trinkala provided a sworn statement in February 1970, discussing his conscientious objector status, his discharge, and his limited contact with Richard Nagell, whom he believed aided his discharge. The investigation also explored Nagell's potential involvement in Trinkala's separation from military service.
significance: Victor L. Trinkala's significance in the JFK context lies in his connection to Richard C. Nagell, who is a figure of interest in some JFK assassination theories. The investigation into Trinkala's underage enlistment and discharge, and Nagell's possible role in it, suggests a potential link between Nagell and individuals who may have been of interest to investigators.
